Package io.avery.conveyor

Class FailureHandlingScope

java.lang.Object
java.util.concurrent.StructuredTaskScopePREVIEW<Object>
io.avery.conveyor.FailureHandlingScope
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable
public final class FailureHandlingScope extends StructuredTaskScopePREVIEW<Object>
FailureHandlingScope relies on preview features of the Java platform:
  • FailureHandlingScope refers to one or more preview APIs: StructuredTaskScope<T>, Subtask<T>.
Programs can only use FailureHandlingScope when preview features are enabled.
Preview features may be removed in a future release, or upgraded to permanent features of the Java platform.
A StructuredTaskScope that handles exceptions from failed tasks by delegating to a handler. The handler may choose to log or aggregate failures, for example. Once the scope is shutdownPREVIEW (including by closing it), tasks no longer report completion, so the handler will no longer be called.

  • Constructor Details

    • FailureHandlingScope

      public FailureHandlingScope(String name, ThreadFactory factory, Consumer<? super Throwable> exceptionHandler)
      Constructs a new FailureHandlingScope with the given name and thread factory, that delegates failure handling to the exceptionHandler. The handler may be called concurrently as tasks complete.

      The task scope is optionally named for the purposes of monitoring and management. The thread factory is used to create threads when subtasks are forkedPREVIEW. The task scope is owned by the current thread.

      Parameters:
      name - the name of the task scope, can be null
      factory - the thread factory
      exceptionHandler - the exception handler

    • FailureHandlingScope

      public FailureHandlingScope(Consumer<? super Throwable> exceptionHandler)
      Constructs a new unnamed FailureHandlingScope that creates virtual threads and delegates failure handling to the exceptionHandler. The handler may be called concurrently as tasks complete.
      Parameters:
      exceptionHandler - the exception handler
      Implementation Requirements
      This constructor is equivalent to invoking the 3-arg constructor with a name of null and a thread factory that creates virtual threads.
